author: mratsim
content:
very interesting.

Since all curves used in blockchain have high 2-adicity, this would accelerate even sqrt-friendly curves with p = 3 (mod 4) like BN254 or BLS12-381.
I'm thinking in particular of point decompression which is a bottleneck in some protocols.

author: gottfriedherold
content:
<@570268431522201601> You may be confusing p with the elliptic curve group size:
The relevant quantity p for square roots as part of point decompression is the size of the field of definition (and its 2-adicity). The size of the elliptic curve group (i.e. the number of points on the relevant (sub-)group) and its 2-adicity is not relevant.
Having p = 3 mod 4 means that the 2-adicity is very low and there is no potential for further acceleration of square roots; it's already sqrt-friendly.
For BLS12-381, you indeed have p=3 mod 4, meaning essentially no 2-adicity for the field of definition. It's the size of the elliptic curve subgroup that has high 2-adicity, but that doesn't harm here.

For Bandersnatch, the size of the field of definition is chosen to be the size of BLS12-381's elliptic curve subgroup, which is why it matters a lot for Bandersnatch.
